item.title: Violence Ebbs but Mexico Remains on Edge After Killing of Cartel Boss
item.description: Many residents and tourists stayed indoors a day after a military raid targeted a leader known as El Mencho, setting off violence across the country. Officials said at least 62 people died in the operation and its aftermath.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times

item.title: Drug Lord ‘El Mencho’ Was Killed in Mexico. What’s Next for the Cartel He Led?
item.description: The death of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes dealt a major blow to the Jalisco New Generation Cartel, but few believe it spells the end for the powerful group.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Alfredo Estrella/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Security forces patrolling in Mexico City after the killing of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes on Sunday.

item.title: Peter Mandelson, Ex-Ambassador to the U.S., Is Released After U.K. Arrest Amid Epstein Accusations
item.description: Peter Mandelson was arrested on Monday on suspicion of “misconduct in public office” following revelations about his dealings with Jeffrey Epstein, the sex offender.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Reuters

item.title: For Iran’s Rulers, Refusing U.S. Demands Is a Risk Worth Taking
item.description: The government in Tehran sees capitulating to Washington’s demands on uranium enrichment and ballistic missiles as riskier to its survival than going to war, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A march in Tehran this month marked the anniversary of the Islamic revolution. Iran is facing an economic crisis and a major buildup of U.S. firepower in the Persian Gulf.

item.title: Settlers in the Israeli-Occupied West Bank Drive a Palestinian Family Off Its Land
item.description: For two years, settlers attacked Rezeq Abu Naim’s land in the Israeli-occupied West Bank at all hours and in all manners. After another violent incursion over the weekend, his family abandoned their home.
item.dc:creator: Azam Ahmed
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: Rezeq Abu Naim, left, with some members of his family inside a cave the family used, in July, near the West Bank village of Al Mughayir.

item.title: EU Support for Ukraine Stumbles as Hungary Looks to Delay Aid
item.description: Hungary said that it would block both the latest sanctions package on Russia and a financial aid package to Kyiv worth about $106 billion.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers at the site of an explosion in Lviv, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: The Ukrainian Bureaucrat Working to Squeeze Russia’s War Machine
item.description: Vladyslav Vlasiuk has spent the past four years pressing Western allies to squeeze the Russian economy through more sanctions. He hopes that 2026 will be the tipping point.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vladyslav Vlasiuk, the Ukrainian commissioner for sanctions policy, in Kyiv, in January.

item.title: France Summons U.S. Ambassador Over Comments on Activist’s Killing
item.description: Charles Kushner, President Trump’s envoy to Paris, was called in after the State Department cited “violent radical leftism” in the beating death of Quentin Deranque, 23.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Ludovic Marin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Charles Kushner, the U.S. ambassador to France, and his wife, Seryl Kushner, leaving the Élysée Palace in Paris in July.

item.title: Tour Montparnasse Is One of Paris’s Uglier Landmarks. It’s Getting a Makeover.
item.description: The Tour Montparnasse is one of Paris’s least-loved landmarks. After half a century, it’s finally being remodeled.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler, Ségolène Le Stradic and Dmitry Kostyukov
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

item.title: The Ex-Taxi Driver at the Center of Russia’s Shadow War
item.description: The Kremlin’s sabotage campaign against European allies of Ukraine has been escalating. It needs people like Aleksei Kolosovsky, 42, to carry it out.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Norbert Ofmanski/Associated Press
item.media:description: A 2024 arson attack outside Warsaw was one of several plots carried out in Europe by a criminal network on behalf of Russian intelligence services, according to European officials.

item.title: Mexican Forces Kill ‘El Mencho,’ Nation’s Most-Wanted Cartel Boss
item.description: “El Mencho” was the longtime head of one of the nation’s most powerful cartels. Armed groups set fire to cars and buildings across Mexico in the wake of his death.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Paulina Villegas
item.media:credit: Gilberto Gallo/Reuters
item.media:description: Agentes de policía aseguran una zona en la que miembros del crimen organizado incendiaron vehículos en Zapopan, México, el domingo.

item.title: Iran Students Protest for Second Day Despite State Crackdown
item.description: Student groups reported protests at universities in Iran’s two largest cities as the government grapples with domestic discontent and the threat of U.S. strikes.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Sanam Mahoozi and Devon Lum
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A screen grab from a social media post that was verified by The New York Times showing demonstrators at the Tehran University of Art on Sunday.

item.title: St. Francis’ Remains, Rarely Seen, Go on Display in Assisi
item.description: The bones of Italy’s patron saint will be shown to the public for a month, to mark the 800th anniversary of his death.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Gregorio Borgia/Associated Press
item.media:description: Believers lined up to see the bones of St. Francis at the basilica bearing his name in Assisi, Italy, on Sunday.

item.title: Inside Iran’s Preparations for War and Plans for Survival
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has entrusted Ali Larijani, the top national security official, to ensure the Islamic Republic endures any military attacks and targeted killings.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ali Larijani, the secretary of the Supreme National Security Council of Iran, in May 2024.

item.title: These Ukrainians Don’t Want to Be Traded to Russia for Peace
item.description: Four years into the war, a major sticking point in talks is control of the eastern Donetsk region. Residents could face an agonizing choice if Ukraine gives up the territory.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Lynsey Addario and Tyler Hicks
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Daria Bondareva last month with a customer at her salon in Sloviansk, Ukraine, in the Donetsk region.

item.title: After Six Decades of the War on Drugs, What Works?
item.description: The U.S. and its allies have spilled blood and treasure to kill drug lords and defeat cartels, but the drugs keep coming and the new groups are more violent than ever.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A burned car in Guadalajara following the capture and killing of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes.

item.title: What Brontë Country Tells Us About Britain Today
item.description: West Yorkshire, where the original “Wuthering Heights” was written, offers a window into the forces that are disrupting British politics.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Andrew Testa
item.media:description: The windswept area of northern England where Emily Brontë wrote “Wuthering Heights” remains a place of startling natural beauty.

item.title: How Russia Put Its Future at Risk by Remaking Its Economy for War
item.description: About half of the country’s federal budget goes toward the fight in Ukraine, money that does little to support its long-term development.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:credit: Kirill Kudryavtsev/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Russian troops during a rehearsal of the Victory Day military parade in Moscow, last year.

item.title: The Looming Taiwan Chip Disaster That Silicon Valley Has Long Ignored
item.description: If China invades Taiwan and cuts off its chip exports to American companies, the tech industry and the U.S. economy would be crippled.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Ben Jones; Source Photographs by Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times; Loren Elliott for The New York Times; Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: ‘Mother Russia’ Review: A New Play That’s as Funny as It’s Smart
item.description: A strong cast stars in Lauren Yee’s new play, part of a cycle of works about the collisions between 20th-century communism and pop culture.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: Steven Boyer as Dmitri and Adam Chanler-Berat as Evgeny getting a taste of capitalism in Lauren Yee’s “Mother Russia” at the Signature Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: After Chaos Rips Across Mexico, the Remnants of Cartel Violence Haunt Residents
item.description: Charred vehicles cluttered deserted streets as residents started to emerge from their homes in Guadalajara, which was hit hard by violence after the death of a cartel leader.
item.dc:creator: Paulina Villegas and César Rodríguez
item.media:credit: César Rodríguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Empty streets and closed businesses on Monday in downtown Guadalajara.

item.title: Hunkering Down in Mexico, Some Hope for a Flight Out Amid Burning Cars
item.description: People from Canada and the United States tell of scrambling for safety, food and flights after violence erupted in Mexico when a cartel boss died in custody.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: Tourists watching a smoke rising after cartel members blocked roads and burned down businesses after a military operation led to the death of the Mexican drug lord Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico.

item.title: Canada to Probe What OpenAI Knew About Tumbler Ridge Shooter
item.description: The company suspended the killer’s ChatGPT account over a policy violation in June, eight months before the attacks in Tumbler Ridge, British Columbia.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for the victims of a the mass shooting this month at Tumbler Ridge Secondary School in British Columbia.

item.title: Mexican Forces Say They Tracked El Mencho to Cabin by Following His Lover
item.description: Top security officials revealed details of the operation that led to the death of Mexico’s most wanted drug cartel leader.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Yuri Cortez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gen. Ricardo Trevilla Trejo, Mexico’s defense minister, described this weekend’s operation against a top cartel leader at a news conference in Mexico City on Monday with President Claudia Sheinbaum.

item.title: C.I.A. Intelligence Helped Lead Mexican Authorities to ‘El Mencho’
item.description: Mexican officials said they had found the elusive cartel kingpin by tracking a romantic partner. The C.I.A. provided some intelligence critical to the operation.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Alfredo Estrella/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mexican special forces in Mexico City on Sunday. C.I.A. intelligence helped lead the special forces to the cartel leader.

item.title: Europe’s New Way of War
item.description: Can Europe defend itself without the United States? A new strategic vision says yes.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

item.title: Videos Show How Violence Unfolded in Mexico After Killing of Cartel Boss
item.description: Armed groups blocked roads and set fire to supermarkets and banks after the Mexican government killed Mexico’s most-wanted cartel boss.
item.dc:creator: Devon Lum and Pablo Robles

item.title: Who Is Peter Mandelson, the UK Ex-Ambassador Fired Over His Epstein Ties?
item.description: The former British ambassador to the United States was arrested on Monday, months after being fired over his ties to Jeffrey Epstein, the convicted sex offender.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Ben Birchall/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Peter Mandelson leaving his home in Wiltshire, England, on Friday. He spent four decades in British politics, most recently as ambassador to the United States.

item.title: The European Union Hits Pause on Its U.S. Trade Deal
item.description: The E.U. isn’t throwing out the deal it agreed with the United States before President Trump’s tariffs were overruled, but European officials want more clarity first.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Lea Meienberg for The New York Times
item.media:description: A European lawmaker warned that U.S. tariffs on cheeses like Parmesan and Camembert could nearly double, to about 30 percent.

item.title: Trump Administration Scrambles to Pick Up the Pieces of Broken Tariffs
item.description: President Trump is already working to piece his tariff program back together, after a Supreme Court ruling ruptured a centerpiece of his economic agenda.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has said that tariffs will help America’s manufacturing sector and create factory jobs, though many economists have questioned those claims.

item.title: Puerto Vallarta Jolted By Violence After Cartel Boss Killing
item.description: When violence broke out after the killing of Mexico’s most-wanted cartel boss, vacation spots ordinarily spared from the drug wars were also targeted.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and David Shortell
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: Firefighters work to extinguish a bus on fire in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, Sunday.

item.title: Supreme Court to Weigh Oil-Industry Effort to End a Major Climate Suit
item.description: The case could have significant bearing on a range of other lawsuits brought against the fossil fuel industry by cities and states across the country.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Rachel Ellis/The Denver Post, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A Suncor Energy oil refinery in Commerce City, Colo.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and James Wagner

item.title: Women’s Olympic Hockey Gold Medalist Has Her Brothers’ Eccentric Support
item.description: The three brothers of Haley Winn, a defender for the U.S. squad, gained a spotlight for the colorful ways they cheered on their sister’s dream.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.media:credit: Petr David Josek/Associated Press
item.media:description: Haley Winn celebrates her gold medal in Milan on Thursday with her brothers Ryan, left, Tommy and Casey Winn.

item.title: Supreme Court Considers Fate of Docks and Other Assets Seized by Cuba in 1960
item.description: Amid rising tensions with Cuba, the Trump administration is backing lawsuits that would allow Americans to get compensation for property confiscated by Fidel Castro’s regime.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Havana Docks Company
item.media:description: Revolutionaries confiscated the property of the Havana Docks Company in 1960.

item.title: The Japanese Airport That Doesn’t Lose Bags
item.description: Kansai International Airport, which is located near Osaka, Japan, hasn’t lost a single piece of luggage since it opened in 1994. River Akira Davis, our Tokyo correspondent, visited the airport to understand how Japanese culture has influenced its success.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis, Nailah Morgan, Jon Hazell, Stephanie Swart, Daishi Kusunoki and Hisako Ueno

item.title: The Zero Units Fought for the C.I.A. in Afghanistan. In the U.S., They’re Living in Fear.
item.description: A shooting in Washington, D.C., threw their immigration status into jeopardy — and brought attention to a long-hidden dimension of America’s war.
item.dc:creator: Matthieu Aikins and Wesley Morgan
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mohammad Iqbal

item.title: Duterte Won’t Appear at Hearing as I.C.C. Weighs Evidence Against Him
item.description: The former leader of the Philippines faces a possible trial for the deaths of thousands during his war on drugs. Supporters and opponents gathered in the Netherlands as a key hearing started.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado and Koba Ryckewaert
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Rodrigo Duterte, the former leader of the Philippines, on Saturday outside the International Criminal Court detention center on the outskirts of The Hague.

item.title: What to Know About the Killing of ‘El Mencho’
item.description: The Mexican government has killed Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes, the longtime leader of one of Mexico’s most powerful gangs, the Jalisco New Generation Cartel.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Ulises Ruiz/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Firefighters extinguishing a burning bus blocking a roadway in Jalisco state, Mexico, on Sunday.

item.title: Trump Considers Targeted Strike Against Iran, Followed by Larger Attack
item.description: The top negotiators plan to meet in Geneva on Thursday for last-ditch talks, debating a new proposal that could create an off-ramp as two carrier groups massed within striking distance of Iran.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, David E. Sanger, Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s threat is the latest example of how he is trying to force Iranian leaders to see that they have no choice but to give up every aspect of their nuclear program.

item.title: Courting China Again
item.description: The German chancellor will travel to Beijing this week, the latest high-level visitor as Western countries pivot back to China.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Kin Cheung
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain in Shanghai last month.

item.title: ‘This Has Been a Day:’ U.S.-Canada Hockey Game Puts Rivalry on the Line
item.description: Canadians and Americans jammed bars that opened early on Sunday to watch the United States deal the Canadian team, and the country, a devastating blow in overtime.
item.dc:creator: Shawna Richer and Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the Canuck in Manhattan on Sunday, a handful of U.S. fans watched among a largely pro-Canada crowd.

item.title: Iran Could Direct Proxies to Attack U.S. Targets Abroad, Officials Warn
item.description: Security officials are monitoring increasingly worrisome signs as President Trump considers another military campaign against Iran.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new billboard in Tehran this month. The uncertainty surrounding possible threats from Iran’s proxy groups further complicates the Trump administration’s war planning.

item.title: Arab Leaders Condemn Remarks by U.S. Ambassador to Israel
item.description: The ambassador, Mike Huckabee, seemed to endorse Israeli control of lands stretching from Egypt to Iraq. He said his comments were taken out of context.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Ohad Zwigenberg/Associated Press
item.media:description: Ambassador Mike Huckabee told Tucker Carlson, the podcaster, that it “would be fine” if Israel “took it all,” referring to much of the Middle East. Arab and Islamic countries denounced his remarks.

item.title: Trump Tensions Turn U.S.-Canada Olympic Hockey Final Into a ‘Grudge Match’
item.description: The tensions between the Trump administration and Canada were largely cast aside at the men’s Olympic gold medal game, which the U.S. team won in overtime.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. men’s hockey team prepares to take the ice against Canada in the gold medal match in Milan on Sunday.

item.title: Russia Attacks Ukraine Ahead of Invasion’s 4th Anniversary
item.description: At least one man was killed in Kyiv as Moscow launched a wave of drones and missiles, days after the latest round of U.S.-mediated talks to end the war.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers at the site where a policewoman was killed in an explosion in Lviv, Ukraine, on Sunday. It was not clear whether Russia was involved.

item.title: Fat Signing Bonuses, and Concierge Service, for Family Doctors
item.description: In a country where a quarter of the population lacks a family doctor, Canadian communities compete in a zero-sum battle to recruit family doctors.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Gavin John
item.media:credit: Gavin John for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town of Stettler, Alberta’s economy is predominantly driven by the agriculture and oil industries, and is the largest town for surrounding communities.

item.title: Trump Looks Ahead to Summit With China’s Xi, but Tariffs and Taiwan Loom
item.description: President Trump said his planned meeting with President Xi Jinping would be a grand display, but tensions over trade and defense could dampen the mood.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: The last time President Trump and President Xi Jinping of China met was in October in Busan, South Korea.

item.title: Johannes Hoesflot Klaebo Leads Norway to Record Olympic Medal Haul
item.description: Norway, led by the cross-country skiing sensation Johannes Hoesflot Klaebo, topped the medal table for the fourth straight Winter Games.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Louise Krüger
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrons watching the closing ceremony of the Winter Olympics at a local sports bar in Tromso, Norway, on Sunday.

item.title: The A.I. Evangelists on a Mission to Shake Up Japan
item.description: Team Mirai, a political party founded by software engineers, won 11 seats in Japan’s legislature by promising chatbots, self-driving buses and high-tech jobs.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:credit: Kentaro Takahashi for The New York Times

item.title: Iran’s Students Hold Anti-Regime Protests as Universities Reopen
item.description: Students helped grow initial protests into a national movement crushed by the government. As the new semester began, they chanted and marched again.
item.dc:creator: Leily Nikounazar, Pranav Baskar and Devon Lum
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathering at Amirkabir University in Tehran, in an image from a social media post that was verified by The New York Times.

item.title: For Dutch speedskater, age doesn’t matter.
item.description: Jorrit Bergsma, a gold medalist back in 2014, is now 40. But he rolled back the years to win gold.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Doug Mills
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: The Queen Stuck by Prince Andrew. King Charles Is Pulling Away
item.description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, the former prince, is getting no help from the throne as the crisis over his ties to Jeffrey Epstein intensifies.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Richard Pohle
item.media:description: Prince Andrew, as he was then known, escorted his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, to a memorial service for his father, Prince Philip, at Westminster Abbey in London in March 2022.

item.title: At Least 10 Killed in Lebanon, Officials Say, After Israel Strikes Hezbollah
item.description: The Lebanese militant group said eight of its members were among those killed late Friday. The attacks threaten to further destabilize an already tenuous cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Bilal Hussein/Associated Press
item.media:description: Coffins draped in fabric bearing the symbol of Hezbollah are carried through the village of Nabi Sheet, eastern Lebanon, on Saturday.

item.title: Young Skaters Assist With Figure Skating Competitions While Aspiring to the Olympics
item.description: Young skaters known as flower kids jump into action. They have their own Olympic dreams.
item.dc:creator: Weiyi Cai

item.title: Searching for Rejuvenation Where Skiers Chase Olympic Gold
item.description: The thermal waters of the Italian Alps, long praised for their restorative properties, are well known to elite athletes. During the Winter Games, they’ve drawn spectators, too.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei and Gabriela Bhaskar

item.title: Future Perfect
item.description: Does taking care of our future selves have to mean sacrifice in the present?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Klaebo Makes Olympic History: Unforgettable Photos from 6-Gold Sweep
item.description: Johannes Klaebo won his sixth cross country gold medal at the 2026 Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Vincent Alban
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
